events.name: Open Hamilton Event: Building Hamilton's version of Change By Us
events.about:
We will be holding a mini-hackathon at think|haus, 25 Dundurn St N in Hamilton, at 7pm Monday to launch the Hamilton Version.

We need everyone, including people with the following skill sets:

  • Developers - we want to create the best fork of Change By Us anywhere, creating a site Hamiltonians can be proud of. Our code will make the site powerful for Hamiltonians and be offered by to the main project, putting Hamilton on the open government map.
  • Designers - This isnt a cheap rip-off of some template we found the Internet. We need your skills to make the user interface reflect all the beauty and greatness that is our city. Take a look at other sites using Change By Us, including NYC and Philly, as the baseline. What designer changes will make our better? See you Monday.
  • City Knowledge Experts - Do you work for the City? Have you worked for the City? Are you engaged in neighbourhood associations or community groups? We need you. You our are experts on what our HamOnt version of Change By Us needs to connect to our fellow citizens to our city to ensure the success of this project.
  • Stats Gurus - Theres a social science to engagement and feedback collection. We need you to ensure we create a product that will ensure our fellow citizens are being properly heard.
  • Citizens / Testing & Documentation - We need people to bring ideas, test the product to make sure it works, and assist with documentation for others. 

This doesnt happen without you. Bring your ideas, cheer us on, and help spread the word.

How to prepare for tonight:

  • Bring your ideas;
  • if you are a github user, please visit: https://github.com/OpenHamilton/Hamilton-modded-Change-By-Us to see the code we are modifying (and please include your github account name in your registration);
  • Think about the next steps - how do we ensure this isnt a one-time one-off colloboration between us and the City;
  • Prepare for an awesome night of positive energy.

Outline of tonights schedule

7:00 p.m. - opening greetings from think|haus (our host) and Councillor Brian McHattie - the mover of the motion calling for Council to adopt open data.

7:15 p.m. - break into working groups and plan strategy until 7:45 p.m.

7:45 p.m. - regroup, confirm plan, and start building. ALPHA version launch at 9pm

9:00 p.m. - assess ALPHA and prepared to quickly move to BETA

9:45 p.m. - launch BETA and set next event date

 

How we got here today:

Open Hamilton was formed by a group of citizens who meet at The Mulberry Cafe on October 30, 2010.

Weve held numerous events and lobbied City Hall for open data. 

Open Hamilton has been playing a series of projects for International Open Data Day on February 23rd, among those projects is modifying Change By Us. 

Weve been working with the City Managers Office and staff to create the conditions for open data success at City Hall and we hope that in the first part of 2013 we will be close to having Council approve open data initiative.

It was hoped that we would partner with the City to hold a joint event for Open Data Day. These discussions had begun, and we felt the City was very receptive to the idea. 

City Council will hopefully soon approve Open Data. Open Hamilton was consulted extensively during the drafting of the policy. While we have not seen the proposed policy, because it has not been given to Council, we are confident that we will happy endorse it. 

It has been a lot of work to get to so many partners on-board at the City. Open Hamilton formed just over two years ago, and we started lobbying for an immediate Open Data policy because Hamilton is so far behind other municipalities. 

We were disappointed to not meet with immediate buy-in from City Hall for a policy. 

Having spent nearly two years working with Councillor Brian McHattie and he City Managers Office, we feel that the policy when it comes forward will advance us further than having had a policy passed two years ago.

We, Open Hamilton, Councillor McHattie and other Councillors supporting Open Data from the start, and the City Managers office have used the past two years to build allies within City Hall for a successful implementation of Open Data when it occurs. 

Our meetup Monday is spurred by the events of this past week. It is more clear now than on Monday that an appetite exists for collaboration with City Hall - both inside and outside of 71 Main. 

Councillor McHattie and Michael Kirkopoulos of the City Managers Office will be joining us for this event.

events.name:
Hacathon!
Papurau Newydd Hanesyddol / Historical Newspapers
events.about:
#hacathon

Mae Llyfrgell Genedlaethol Cymru wedi digido bron i filwn o dudalenni o bapurau newydd hanesyddol Cymru, iw lawnsio ym mis Mawrth 2013. Dyma gyfle i gael chwarae gydar data ar delweddau or prosiect cyn iddo gael ei lawnsio ir cyhoedd, gyda mynediad uniongyrchol ir wefan beta ar API syn sylfaen iddi.

Maer Hacathon ar agor i bobl creadigol o bob math yn ogystal â datblygwyr, a daw â phobl gyda syniadau ynghyd â phobl gydar sgiliau iw gweithredu.

Hawliwch docyn drwyr dudalen hon a mi ddanfonwn ni becyn gwybodaeth i chi gyda manylion o amserlen y digwyddiadau syn arwain at yr Hacathon ei hun yn Aberystwyth ar Ionawr y 18fed.

Bydd detholiad o gynnyrch yr Hacathon yn cael ei arddangos yn lawnsiad y wefan yng Nghaerdydd ar y 13eg o Fawrth, 2013. Yn ogystal, bydd gwobrau ar gyfer y datblygiadau gora.

 

The National Library of Wales has digitised almost a million pages of historical welsh newspapers, to be launched in March 2013. This is an opportunity to play with the data and images from the project before its launched to the public, with direct access to the beta website and the APIs its built on.

The Hacathon is open to all kind of creative people as well as developers, and will bring together people with ideas with people with the know-how to implement them.

Get a ticket from this page and well send you an information pack and details of the timetable of events leading up to the Hacathon in Aberystwyth on January the 18th.

A selection of outputs from the Hacathon will be showcased in the high-profile website launch event in Cardiff on the 13th of March, 2013. Prizes will also be awarded for the best developments.

events.name: Sprout - Hackathon 6
Everyone Hacks
events.about:
If youve ever wanted to learn how to build an app, or how to build with a team, or what these hackathon things are all about, this event is for you. We provide you with food, power, motivational drinks, and guidance. You bring your toolset (laptop, Wacom tablet, favorite pen, brain) and a willingness to hack.

 A hackathon is a gathering of diverse people around challenges who work on addressing those challenges. While traditionally geared towards the technical, a recent understanding and appreciation of design, social integration, and business have made these events much more diverse

Everyone Hacks is designed to create safe space while expanding what you think youre capable of. In a collaborative setting, youll produce a surprising amount of work in a very short period of time, both with people you have only just met and old friends. The event is reaching out to women who are interested in these events, and is definitely transgender and queer friendly. Male-bodied folk are more than welcome, but please come as a guest of someone who is non-cis-male.

While we know you will rock it, here is a listing of some great meetups and workshops to attend before the event to meet other attendees and get a solid understanding of the many skill sets that are useful at hackathons.

GirlDevelopIt Events:

  • Jan. 7th, SF: Multimedia in HTML5
  • Jan. 7-10, SF: Intro to JS Workshop

Other Events:

  • Jan. 7th, SF: SF JS: OpenSourcing your JS Project
  • Jan. 10th, SF: WomenWhoCode Lightning Talks
  • Jan. 10th, SF: GA’s Business Operation for Startups
  • Jan. 13th, Palo Alto: Shared Learning Collaborative Camp (Education Hackathon)
  • Jan. 14th, SF: SFJS Pair Programming Night
  • Jan. 17th, SF: Building Products with Ruby on Rails
  • Jan. 31st, MTV: CodeChix Security Architecutes & Coding Communication

Already a hackathon veteran? Welcome back! Come see some fresh faces and rethink normal.

Our hashtag will be #everyonehacks - find fellow attendees on twitter!


Schedule:

Friday, well open our doors at 18:00 for meet-and-greet, drinks, and short talks from some fine folk.

Saturday

  • Doors open at 09:00 for breakfast and that sweet nectar of life, coffee.
  • Half-hour workshops run from 10 to noon on a variety of topics, from node.JS to Allies Training
  • Lunch is served and start hacking!

Sunday

  • Return home from sleeping to breakfast at 09:00
  • Teams present to judges at 16:00.

The entirity of the event takes place at NextSpace Union Square. Having trouble finding it? Check out their page!


Prizes so far include:

  • The winner will be recognized and invited to a dinner and reception at the Women’s Technology Leadership Forum at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel, San Francisco on 25th February 2013. The inaugural Women’s Technology Leadership Forum is hosted by HP and will be attended by senior executive women in technology from Fortune 500 companies
  • A paid spot to the gender-based-violence hackathon in Port-au-Prince first weekend of February with Digital Democracy via Tropo.
  • A ticket to Renaissance iOS App Makers Conference for the Everyone Hacks participant with the most potential.
  • Books from No Starch Press
  • Spheros from SendGrid
  • HP products via HP

events.name: CrisisCamp Boston - January 2013
events.about:
CrisisCamp brings together domain experts, developers, and first responders around improving technology and practice for humanitarian crisis management and disaster relief.

Each and every day, people across the world can find themselves in crisis. Whether it be for a day, a month or an area of social distress, we all have a common need to connect with loved ones, access information and offer assistance to others.

CrisisCamps are hosted in a barcamp style where great minds come together to share their knowledge and expertise for social good.

In response to Hurricane Sandy a group of netizens began to congregate online via etherpads, Google Docs, and IRC calling themselves Hurricane Hackers. In trying to find a fit between a predominant set of technological skills and Sandy needs, HurricaneHackers converged with SandyCrisisCamps and rebooted CrisisCamp Boston in conjunction with a globally coordinated hackathon held November 3rd.

It quickly became clear that effective crisis response is built upon preexisting disaster preparedness efforts which is why we are organizing a series of 2013 CrisisCamp Boston hackathons!

Come design, code, and learn with other people at the MIT Media Lab. Even if you arent a software developer there will be plenty to do including sharing experiences and ideas, documenting activity, running social media communications, taking and editing video, organizing future events, etc!

This event is free and open to the public.

Come prepared:

  • Make sure your programs are up to date.
  • Learn how github works.
  • Review projects and lessons learned from the last CrisisCamp Boston.
  • Check out the CrisisCamp Boston page on the CrisisCommons wiki for more information.

Connect with other CrisisCampers on

  • Twitter
  • Google Groups
  • Facebook

There will also be local Subject Matter Experts (SMEs) on hand to discuss how technology can be used (and not) in crisis situations.

About CrisisCommons - http://crisiscommons.org/

CrisisCommons seeks to advance and support the use of open data and volunteer technology communities to catalyze innovation in crisis management and global development.

CrisisCommons is a global community of volunteers from technology, crisis response organizations, government agencies, and citizens that are working together to build and use technology tools to help respond to disasters and improve resiliency and response before a crisis.

events.name: AttorneyFee's "I have a dream" Hackathon
events.about:
Who: Legal tech enthusiasts in the Bay area

What: The first ever AttorneyFee hackathon

Where: 1911 Landings Avenue, Mountain View CA

When: Jan 20th at 10:00 AM till Jan 21 at 5:00 PM

AttorneyFee is holding its first hackathon ever, and we want you to join us! The event will kick off at 10:00 AM on January 20th and go till the next day at 5:00 PM. Copious amounts of caffeine, pizza, and beer will be provided. Come with a team, or come on your own and join a team. Come with an idea to work on, or join our ideation session in the morning to develop an idea. At the conclusion of the event each team will present their project, and the coolest project will win some swag.

The focus of the hackathon will be trademarks. Why trademarks, you ask? We recently finished building three super valuable APIs for trademarks that we hope will enable more open innovation in the space: (i) the AF TM applications API, (ii) the AF TM attorneys API, and (iii) the AF TM logos API. Together, these three APIs should enable devs to build a slew of cool new apps to disrupt the trademark industry.

More to the point, everyone who files a trademark application does so because they believe that their name, logo, or brand will become incredibly valuable in the future and worthy of protection. In other words, people file trademarks when they are dreaming of a grandiose future, and we thought that there would be nothing more fitting than to commemorate these dreams on Martin Luther King weekend.

Please RSVP below so that we can make sure that our pizza procurement strategy matches headcount. If anyone wants to come but needs a ride from the Cal Train, email Richard@AttorneyFee.com.

events.name: Research to Impact Hackathon: agriculture and nutrition
events.about:
Research to Impact Hackathon: agriculture and nutrition
Linking information and data, and taking it to where it is needed

Every year institutions, researchers and practitioners generate thousands of datasets, reports and articles about development issues. Yet, much of this knowledge remains underused , locked away in silos. The Institute for Development Studies (IDS), and Research for Development (R4D) have been working to open up access to research information, creating open APIs allowing anyone to tap into over 15 years of curated development research.

Open data on the web makes it possible to take information on research from many sources, and to generate ‘mash-ups’ that make it available in different places, on different platforms, and in ways that support action and impact. Open data can be remixed to answer key questions in ways that were not possible before.

In this hackathon focussed on agriculture and nutrition we will bring together subject matter experts with tech developers to explore create innovative prototypes to increase the use and impact of research in development.


Subject experts on agriculture and nutrition policy and practice are invited to join us on all day on Tuesday 22nd January to explore key needs for access to research and data. Through a facilitated workshop together we will come up with problem statements to present in the afternoon.

Developers are invited to apply to take part and to join us from the afternoon of the 22nd January to hear about the challenges identified by our subject experts, and then to spend 23rd and 24th January working on building prototype solutions.

On the 25th January we all come back together for a showcase of the prototypes created, judging of the best prototype, and to explore ways to take forward better use of open data and research to inform practice.

Subject experts can also take part on the 23rd - 24th where expert support will be available for you to explore the available open data and resources to answer particular policy questions, and there will opportunities to work with the developers to help shape the prototypes under development.


There will be a prize - the best prototype will be awarded a package of financial and practical support to take forward future development of the idea (details to be confirmed). Lunch and refreshments will be provided. Travel expenses will be covered.

This Hackathon will bring together a broad spectrum of people (scientists, architects, sustainability experts, economists, government researchers, policy makers, design thinkers, developers, programmers and creatives) to create real ways to protect the environment.

Ahead of our hackathon weekend in January, we are organizing a Amazon Web Services and SAP Research Labs workshop session. AWS and SAP are providing our participants with their software for FREE during the hackathon. This event is for people who would like to learn how they can use these technologies to create solutions that can reduce our environmental impact.There will also be a session by WWFs Earth Hour team  to introduce the themes of the hackathon and propose potential ideas that could be implemented over the weekend.

Even if you are not very tech-savvy or a programmer, you are welcome to attend this session and hear from speakers from WWF, AWS and SAP Research Labs.

events.name: Microsoft Recruiting Info Session & Hackathon Kickoff
events.about:
This three-hour evening workshop is designed to give you the jump-start you need to take advantage of the biggest opportunity for up-and-coming developers this decade. With over 500 million Windows 8 devices slated to join the Windows ecosystem this year, there has never been a bigger opportunity for students to build an app that can get you the experience (and income!) that will help you achieve your goals.  It also will give you a chance to show your stuff to Microsoft recruiters who will be on-site to explain why Microsoft is one of the top places to work in America, and to help you explore if were the right place for you after graduation.

This Thursday evening event kicks off a month-long competition that will conclude February 22nd with an all-day Hack-a-thon where youll get expert instruction and help to finish your project, and where your app will be judged by all and valuable prizes awarded to the top apps.

The tentative agenda for the kick-off is:

6:00pm Pizza Meet and Greet with Microsoft Recruiters and Tech Evangelists

6:30pm Windows 8: The Big Opportunity for Developers

7:00pm App Development Workflow and Store Ecosystem

7:30pm Overview of Visual Studio and Blend for Store Apps

8:00pm App Dev Demos

8:30pm Review of tutorials, how-tos, templates, and other resources

This workshop is being held in a theater-setting rather than a furnished computer lab. Most of the content will be presentation-format, but it will be helpful if you bring your computer to follow-along. For the best experience attendees should have Windows 8 and Visual Studio installed (required to build apps). Mac Users will need to install Windows 8 and Visual Studio using Bootcamp, Parallels, or VM Ware.  For those who arent able to do the installation before the workshop, we have 15 loaner USB hard drives with the required software installed, which we will make available for use during the evening workshop on a first-come, first-served basis, but please follow the preparation instructions at: http://blogs.msdn.com/b/mis_laboratory/archive/2012/08/29/preparing-a-computer-to-use-windows-to-go.aspx . Attendees with older Macbooks will need to come with Windows 8 already installed using Bootcamp, VMWare or Parallels. Newer Macs that can boot to USB (Power + Option Key) may be able to use Windows to Go. Please make sure your OS has been fully upgraded to the latest version.

All students are invited!

For questions and additional information contact Randy Guthrie at randy.guthrie@microsoft.com
events.address: Brigham Young University - BYU Wilkinson Student Center Varsity Theater

events.name: Flacknite - GlobalGameJam 2013
events.about:
GGJ Page where attendees should register as Jammers (for the world record)

FlackNite (Farset Labs hack) is a regular programme of 24-hour tech-events. The challenge is simple; finish a technical project or solve a problem in a weekend, and be able to stand up in front of your peers and show off your work. FlackNite offers a platform for the rapid development of projects, as well as a structured and constructive feedback from peers.

This time around were collaborating with the University of Ulsters Office of Innovation to run the 2013 Northern Ireland Global Game Jam

The Global Game Jam (GGJ) is the worlds largest game jam event. Think of it as a hackathon focused on game development. It is the growth of an idea that in today’s heavily connected world, we could come together, be creative, share experiences and express ourselves in a multitude of ways using video games – it is very universal. The weekend stirs a global creative buzz in games… while at the same time exploring the process of development, be it programming, iterative design, narrative exploration or artistic expression. It is all condensed into a 48 hour development cycle. Although the event is heavily focused on programming, there are many other areas where people who don’t code can contribute to a game.

This is going to be an in-demand event so please register attendence beforehand!

Note that Donations are not required for this event as refreshment costs are being covered by UUOI, but donation tickets will go directly into the general Farset fund, for which well be paying the bills to keep Farset going day to day!

events.name: Cleveland Global Game Jam 2013
events.about:
Join the Cleveland Game Devs at the Shaker LaunchHouse for:

Global Game Jam 2013

January 25 - 27, 2013

Event Details:
The Cleveland Game Devs Meetup group will be holding a Global Game Jam (GGJ) event from 5:00 PM EST on Friday, January 25th 2013 through 5:00 PM EST Sunday, January 27th 2013. Game Jams are a unique experience where artists, coders, designers and musicians collaborate to build games over a weekend based on a specific theme. For this event and with our sponsor Handelabra Studios (home of the GAME.minder app) help, we will provide snacks and beverages all weekend long as well as a pizza dinner on Saturday. GGJ Keynotes and theme announcement will start at 6:00 PM Friday night. Final game demos and post-mortems will start at 3:00 PM Sunday.

For this Game Jam, we will be participating in the 4th Annual Global Game Jam. The Global Game Jam (GGJ) is the worlds largest game jam event. Think of it as a hackathon focused on game development. It is the growth of an idea that in today’s heavily connected world, we could come together, be creative, share experiences and express ourselves in a multitude of ways using video games. Although the event is heavily focused on programming, there are many other areas where people who don’t code can contribute to a game.

We will be holding the event at the Shaker|LaunchHouse startup incubator. LaunchHouse (http://launchhouse.com) is a lean new public-private partnership that fosters entrepreneurial success and job creation through seed capital, education and innovation. This Northeast Ohio organization connects new entrepreneurs with proven business leaders in a grassroots, for-profit model that can be successfully replicated nationwide. This is an exciting and unique space that will give our group plenty of room to work. Please note that we will only be using the LaunchHouse space during the hours specified below. We will not be able to provide sleeping locations or overnight access to the facility.

It is recommended that people interested in working within a team form it in advance. Participants will need to bring their own laptops or desktops and whatever software or technology they need for creating games. Wifi Internet access will be available. Participants also have the option to build “paper prototype” games using whatever supplies they wish to bring. 

Location:
Shaker|LaunchHouse
3558 Lee Road
Shaker Heights, OH 44120

Location Hours:
Friday, January 25th - 5:00 PM to 1:00 AM
Saturday, January 26th - 10:00 AM to 1:00 AM
Sunday, January 27th - 10:00 AM to 5:00 PM

Event Times:
Keynotes and Theme Announcement start at 6:00 PM Friday

Project Demos start at 3:00 PM Sunda.

Contact Info:

Please contact Matt Perrin, Organizer for the Cleveland Game
Developers Meetup group if you have any questions or concerns.
Email : mattperrin at gmail.com

Event Rules:
This event is for individuals over 18 years of age with a valid photo ID and signed liability waiver. Those under 18 years of age must have a legal guardian sign the liability waiver. Liability waivers will be handed out at the event entrance and are available in advance. 
The event is non-smoking and use of alcohol or drugs is not permitted.
Attendees are responsible for the security of their belongings during the event. It is recommended that attendees take their belongings home with them each night.
Be excellent to each other. We’re doing this to have fun.

Legal Notices:
By purchasing tickets to this event you are taking sole-responsibility for your actions and possessions at the event. You are agreeing to waive Shaker|LaunchHouse, Cleveland Game Developers and their staff members against any claims or indemnity as a result of any hurt, loss or damage that may be incurred at the event. A signed, legally binding liability waiver is required for all attendees. Attendees also agree to adhere to the guidelines of the Cleveland Game Developers Pro-Diversity /Anti-Harassment policy.

events.name: Global Game Jam - San Francisco
events.about:
The 2013 Global Game Jam is the fifth annual game development hackathon that welcomes creators of all skills, levels and disciplines to gather for one crazy weekend to make some truly cool games. Locations all across the world will host jammers from January 25-27 (Friday afternoon to Sunday evening, nonstop) to turn out record-breaking numbers of games.

Last year, the San Francisco GGJ site hosted close to 80 students, hobbyists, indies, and developers from companies like Zynga, Stupid Fun Club, PopCap, Playforge, and more. 

For more information about the Global Game Jam, head to their website: www.globalgamejam.org

You can also find our specific San Francisco site here: http://globalgamejam.org/sites/2013/san-francisco

events.name: Global Game Jam 2013
events.about:
The Global Game Jam (GGJ) is the worlds largest game jam event. Think of it as a hackathon focused on game development. It is the growth of an idea that in today’s heavily connected world, we could come together, be creative, share experiences and express ourselves in a multitude of ways using video games – it is very universal. The weekend stirs a global creative buzz in games… while at the same time exploring the process of development, be it programming, iterative design, narrative exploration or artistic expression. It is all condensed into a 48 hour development cycle. Although the event is heavily focused on programming, there are many other areas where people who don’t code can contribute to a game.

The structure of a jam is usually that everyone gathers on Friday late afternoon, watches a short video keynote with advice from leading game developers, and then a secret theme is announced. All sites worldwide are then challenged to make games based on that same theme, with games to be completed by Sunday afternoon. In January 2012, we had 242 location in 47 countries created over 2000 games in one weekend and became a Guinness World Record! The jam is known for helping foster new friendship, increase confidence and opportunities within the community. The jam is always an intellectual challenge. People are invited to explore new technology tools, trying on new roles in development and testing their skills to do something that requires them to design, develop create, test and make a new game in the time span of 48 hours.

The GGJ is not a competition.

GGJ is organized by the Global Game Jam, Inc., an international non-profit corporation based in San Luis Obispo, California, with a mission to foster game design and game education through innovative events. The current board of directors:

The GGJ depends on the generous work and support of many other people including sponsors, jam site organizers, and volunteers. Please see the credits page for a more comprehensive list of contributors.

 

hashtag for this event is #ggj13

events.name: Global Game Jam Calgary
events.about:
The Global Game Jam (GGJ) is the worlds largest game jam event. Think of it as a 48 hour hackathon focused on game development.

The GGJ is not a competition.

The jam starts late afternoon on Friday with a short video keynote featuring advice from leading game developers from around the world and the secret theme is announced. All sites worldwide are then challenged to make games based on that same theme, with games to be completed by Sunday afternoon. In January 2012, we had 242 location in 47 countries created over 2000 games in one weekend and became a Guinness World Record! Boom.

GGJ Calgary 2013 is on January 25-27 at the brand new Taylor Family Digital Library on the University of Calgary campus. 

 

 

A bit about the TFDL venue:

The new state-of-the-art learning and research centre is a model for the 21st century library, and an important new gathering place for students, faculty, staff, alumni and the broader Calgary community. The building opened to students and faculty the first week of September 2012, and is already the new heart of the University of Calgary campus.

The Taylor Family Digital Library’s unique features and resources include technology that encourages
experiential learning, exploration and innovative ways of creating new knowledge. The facility is one of the most digitally progressive academic libraries in North America. It combines a library, art gallery, archives, rare collections, a student success centre, and the latest digital tools for learning and research, all using the most advanced technology available.

It also has a pretty rad games collection too. :)

Learn more >

events.name: Sprout - Hackathon 7
AT&T Mobile App Hackathon - Palo Alto
events.about:
Have an app idea or need an app built for your business?

Mobile App Hackathon is an event produced by the AT&T Developer Program  that is designed for attendees (technical & non-technical) to build apps/mobile apps, get fed, compete for prizes across different categories and most importantly: meet new people and scout for teammates to work on new or current projects. Our hackathon will introduce you to the latest cutting edge tools to help deploy your own app with a website backend, fully hosted in the cloud.

We Supply: Quick presentations and code samples that help to bootstrap your hacking, food to keep you going, and caffeine to keep you awake. Along with technical senseis to assist you in building faster, smarter, and with new tools.

You Bring: Your laptop, skills & ideas. Come with a collaborative, team focused mindset and/or team up in advance on Twitter/Facebook/Google+ via the #atthack hashtag. Whether you are a backend person and code in Ruby/PHP/.NET or are a designer and only work with Illustrator, you are invited to attend this event. Every group needs a good balance of talent and your development skills are needed!

Event Schedule.  The following is a list of the weekends agenda:

  • 6PM - Friday Evening - Kickoff event with drinks, networking, and developer dating which leads into idea pitches and team formation.
  • 7PM - Friday Evening - Speakers present (please see below for list)
  • 8PM - Friday Evening - Pitch ideas and form teams
  • 10AM - Saturday Morning -  The fun continues with an all day hackathon. Work with the teams that you formed on Friday night to produce the app spec’d out the night before. Senseis will be available throughout the entire event to help you code up your solution. App submissions will be accepted throughout the day with a deadline of 7PM.
  • 7PM - Saturday Evening - Promptly at 7PM, teams will begin pitching their ventures. Pitches are limited to three (3) minutes per team.

 


Prizes. The following prizes are experiential and geared towards accelerating you towards a successful business as well as expanding your network and industry knowledge:

  • Best Hackathon Overall App 
    • 1st Place - $500 in Gift Cards for the team and one (1) year of the Small service from Github for each team member
    • 2nd Place - $300 in Gift Cards for the team and one (1) year of the Micro service from Github for each team member
    • 3rd Place - $200 in Gift Cards for the team and six (6) months of Micro service from Github for each team member

Judging Criteria. Apps will be judged based on the criteria below and weighted accordingly.  

  • 33% Weight - Ability to clearly articulate what your app does
  • 33% Weight - Originality of idea
  • 33% Weight - Use of Node.JS, Sencha, cloud9ide.com, Heroku, and other technologies
Social Media. 
  • Follow us @hackathonlive for live updates and photos from the event
  • Like us on Facebook! https://www.facebook.com/AttMobileAppHackathon

Legal.

  • Hackathon Terms: http://db.tt/kyPS9ojR

 

Speakers

 
Alex Donn, Senior Marketing Manager at AT&T, is based out of sunny Seattle! His passion is educating developers young and old about mobile application development best practices through events like hackathons that fuse the collective interests of multiple technology and business leaders. He loves bacon and is allergic to all types of gluten. Tim Anglade, handles Developer Relations & Outreach for Apigee. In previous lives, he was a Research Assistant, a Project Manager, a University Lecturer and a CTO but he kept writing code all the while. You may have met him at a conference, during the NOSQL Summer or seen him host the NOSQL Tapes. He’s always up to chat about dev, hacks, apps & tech — so come say hi!
Max Katz, Head of Community and Developer Relations for Tiggzi (http://tiggzi.com), a cloud-based HTML5, jQuery Mobile and PhoneGap mobile app builder. He loves trying out new and cool REST APIs in mobile apps. You can find out what Max is up to on his blog: mkblog.exadel.com and Twitter: @maxkatz. Alex Gaber, is an API Evangelist for Layer 7 Technologies a company that manages over 200 APIs spanning business and government.  Starting as a web developer 15 years ago, Alex grew up in Silicon Valley and is an active member in the hackathon and developer community.  He has a passion for building web and mobile applications that integrate numerous APIs and ideas to create innovative and unique solutions. 
   
   

Senseis

events.name: Windows 8 Unleashed Hackathon!
events.about:
Windows 8 is the single biggest opportunity for developers on Microsoft stack! Live around Columbus, OH and develop for Windows Phone/Windows 8 or simply want to get started? Come join us for our very own Windows 8 Dev Unleashed event brought to you by Microsoft & The Windows Developer User Group (http://thewindowsdeveloperusergroup.com/).


This Windows 8 hackathon-style event is run by your local developer community & completely FREE! Come learn from experts in Windows 8 Store Style App development & kickstart your dream App. Spend the morning with short lectures covering key topics on demand or work on hands-on labs or pair up with someone towards your own Windows 8 App. Compete with your App by the end of day in the hackathon for a chance to win some great prizes!


So, what are you waiting for? Bring your laptop & fresh ideas; well provide the coffee & lunch. Lets get hacking!


PS: Event Pre-Requisites:

  • Windows 8 OS, running on the metal or in a VM. 
  • You can download Windows 8 as an MSDN Subscriber or try the free Evaluation version.
  • Visual Studio 2012. 
  • Visual Studio Express 2012 for Windows 8 is the free version that has all that you need to develop Windows 8 Store Apps or you can download complete versions of Visual Studio as an MSDN Subscriber.
  • Download links @ http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-US/windows/apps/br229516.
  • More information for Dev Unleashed event attendees @ http://devunleashed.com/windows-8-unleashed/windows-8-unleashed-resources/#attendee.

events.name: AnyMeeting WebRTC Hackathon
events.about:
Summary
To be held on January 26, 2013, the “AnyMeeting WebRTC Hackathon,” encourages engineers, designers, product managers, marketers and entrepreneurs to come together and work on building a new project, product or service involving WebRTC in an intense 12 hour hack session.

Thought to be a major game changing technology, WebRTC is an open framework for the web that enables Real Time Communications in the browser. It includes the fundamental building blocks for high quality communications on the web such as network, audio and video components used in voice and video chat applications.

For Participants
The event will begin with a keynote address by AnyMeeting’s CEO, Costin Tuculescu, and a guest speaker (to be announced shortly). Contestants will then break into teams, and the event will officially begin. At the end of the session, each team will have time to present and answer questions about their project, and an awards ceremony will follow.  


Consistently looking to inspire the great spirit of innovation and foster competition, AnyMeeting is offering a grand prize of $5,000 to the winning team. Follow up prizes will be awarded as well. Space is limited - get your ticket today!
 

For Sponsors
Sponsorship opportunities will also be available to companies that are interested in participating.  Contact our Business Development group to inquire about sponsorships. 
 

AnyMeeting has been featured in...

Details
Well be hacking all day, building some awesome things, giving out great prizes, and having a whole lot of fun. 

If you have an idea, get your team members to join. If you dont have a team, register and we will assign you to a team the week before the hackathon. We will reach out to ensure we understand your skills and can assign you to the best team suited to your skills. 

Proposed Schedule (subject to change): 

9 am, Hackathon begins

12 pm, Pizza arrives

4 pm, Krispy Kreme arrives

7 pm, Hacking ends, beer and dinner served

8 pm, Presentations begin

9 pm, Winners chosen and prizes awarded

So, what are you waiting for? Register today!

events.name: MIT Legal Hack-a-Thon
events.about:
Event Page:

    http://iauth.org/event/ (coming soon)

In-Person Attendance:

   The MIT Media Lab and Cambridge Innovation Center.  Current MIT students, faculty and staff are welcome to join the in-person meeting and may do so by registering for a ticket at this Evebtbrite page.  There are limited spots available for non-MIT affiliates to participate at the in-person meetings, to inquire please contact Dazza Greenwood, at: http://ecitizen.mit.edu/contact   

Online Attendance:

Online participation is open to all who register for a ticket at this Evebtbrite page.   

   Live Slides at https://join.me/civics.com

   Conference Call at 712.432.0900 access code 299132#

   Twitter Tags to Follow 

The online participation model will also feature a set of collaboration and group design tools.  

Agenda:

Agenda and materials to follow shortly and will be posted to the Event Page. For more information on the approach to this event, please see: http://ecitizen.mit.edu/mit-legal-hack-a-thon 

Description:

Join the Legal/Technical Integration track at the MIT Media Labs upcoming Personal Data and Trust Framework Hackathon to be held from January 28 through Feb 1st.   Concurrent design and agile development Model System Rules and Contracts with code for OAuth 2 and federated identity credentials for the OpenPDS software will be the anchor of this track.  We will specifically be focused on converging the apps management screen available to a user to see and possibly revoke OAuth 2.0 grants of access to their personal data with a new concept for the Terms of Service page for the PDS - in effect creating a new type of user managed apps and legal terms instrument.  Wireframes, demo code and documentation with memoranda on this approach will be posted at the event page in the coming days and will be provided to all registered participants for this track. 
 
The current main entry for the broader apps development Hack-a-Thon happening concurrently with this legal track is available at: http://student.mit.edu/searchiap/iap-9289af8d3ad05bc3013ad1ab39810064.html 
For more information on this legal track, please contact Dazza Greenwood, at: http://ecitizen.mit.edu/contact

Justin Richer, Lead Technologist at the MITRE Corporation, will give the Keynote, followed by a question and answer session. Justin is an active member of the OpenID Foundations OpenID Connect Working Group and the IETFs OAuth2 Working Group.  The event features several industry leading experts in law, technology and business both from the United States and abroad.  Topics and bios to be posted shortly.

The STC invites your participation in the 2013 Code 4 Cal Hackathon.

What apps do students need? Be innovative! Make a difference!

The goal of the 2013 STC/IEEE Code 4 Cal Hackathon is to provide an environment for students to develop, as a first pass, apps and widgets that meet the information needs of UC Berkeley students.  Students who develop apps and widgets at the Hackathon can follow up by partnering (when feasible) with the potential functional owner to more fully develop the app for submission in the annual STC Web App Competition and potential adoption by the campus.

events.about:
MHacks = Largest Student Hackathon in the Midwest! 
 
This 36-hour hackathon event will be held at the University of Michigan at the Palmer Commons building from Feb 1-3. There will be free food, comfortable lodging provided and great prizes for top hacks!
 
Email hackathon@umich.edu to inquire about FREE transportation for large student groups or an interest in being an MHacks sponsor.

See FAQ below before emailing any questions.

*Sessions: Office hours with companies, breakout sessions, tech talks, company info sessions, interview sessions, and other sponsor-type events that they want to do in their rooms

FAQ
What is the MHacks hackathon?
Hackathons are where it all begins: ideas collide with execution, and students compete to build awesome software applications and hardware devices. MHacks will be a 36-hour straight event for students from Universities across the midwest and around University of Michigan to join together in teams of 1-5 people to build something. MHacks aims to promote entrepreneurship as a viable option both during and after school. 

How do I get there?
 


We want MHacks to be affordable for students all across the country and Canada to attend.  We will be looking into affordable travel options to get you here.  Additionally, we are looking to send buses to the schools that show the most interest.  To inquire about buses, travel subsidies, or other affordable travel options, please feel free to contact 
hackathon@umich.edu.

Is it safe to hack for 36 hours straight at MHacks?
 


Yes; but you have to know how to take care of your body. Students ought to take naps if needed. There will be comfortable and quiet rooms for students to sleep. At the event, there will also be lots of healthy food and beverages for individuals to maintain a level of healthiness.  


What food will be served at MHacks?
 
 
 


We will serve a variety of food from pasta and sandwiches for meals and also have snacks and beverages available around the clock. We will have appropriate vegeterian and gluten-free options as well. 
 



What if I have a food allergy?
 


Please email hackathon@umich.edu to let us know your food allergy and we can set aside allergenic-free food for you. 
 



What if Im not a student, can I participate?
 


We only allow University students to participate; that includes undergradutes and graduates of 2-4 year institutions. 
 



What are the parking options for the event?
 


We are looking into accomodations to gain access to a lot for free parking. We will definitely provide feasible and affordable options for parking cars. More details to come soon!
 



Join the conversations at:
 

http://facebook.com/MHacksHackathon
 

http://twitter.com/mgohack

events.name: DeveloperWeek 2013 Hackathon!
events.about:
The DeveloperWeek Hackathon is a 28-hour app-building contest in downtown San Francisco - and is also the official kick-off of DeveloperWeek 2013! The purpose of the hackathon is to give developers, designers, and entrepreneurs the chance to pitch app ideas - form teams - build a prototype of their app - and present to our hackathon judges for a chance to be one of the top 5 hackathon winners who get “incubated” during DeveloperWeek.

Get all the Hackathon details here!

DeveloperWeek is unlike any other SF hackathon because the top 5 hackathon winners will get 4 days of coaching, 4 days of legal and design services, and free tech tools to help ‘incubate’ their app into a viable startup company by the last day of DeveloperWeek. These 5 hackathon winners then compete again on-stage on Thursday February 7th of DeveloperWeek so our community can help launch your startup!

How can I get involved?

If you already have a team and you know what you want to build, we recommend you complete our scholarship application. The top 25 accepted teams get a free DeveloperWeek Pro Pass! (we will refund your tickets if you buy a ticket but later qualify)

If you do not yet have a team or a solid idea yet then register below Note- if you already have a DeveloperWeek Pass- you do not need to buy a DeveloperWeek Hackathon ticket!

Here are the hackathon rules:

- You can prepare wireframes, outlines, or notes but you cannot start any of your design or development until Saturday February 4th at noon!

- Teams must consist of at least 1 person but at max 5 people

- Your team and your app will be judged based on 3 criteria: 1) Are you solving a real problem in an interesting way? 2) How well did you present? 3) How much progress did you make on your app?

- If you build using a sponsor’s technology then you are also eligible for the sponsor prize!

events.name: TV Hackfest San Francisco 2013 - Hackathon
events.about:
Building Innovation in Multiplatform TV Content Development.

Please sign up on website at http://www.hackfest.tv/northamerica/register.html


Why hack TV?

  1. Because theres half a trillion dollars up for grabs globally in TV ad spend and Pay TV revenue as the Internet starts to collide with traditional TV. According to Forbes.
  2. Print and Music were both disrupted by the Internet. TV is next. Opportunities abound as the current value chain is under threat with new gatekeepers in the living room (Samsung, Google, Apple, Boxee, Roku etc.) and new consumer behaviour with second screen engagement whilst watching TV.
  3. Because we can... now that TVs are getting Smart and Second Screen Social TV is moving into the ecosystem.

All of us can agree on one thing - audiovisual entertainment via television has the most impact in delivering a brand message. Its the backbone of a multi-billion dollar a year global value chain and has been around for over half a century.

But thats going to change.

  1. Media stacking (second screen engagement) becomes a norm rather than a niche behaviour.
  2. Ad-skipping is on the rise.
  3. The old model of distribution with broadcasters delivering mass audiences to brands and agencies is over due to audience fragmentation and more niche viewing and more content.

The tasks can include things like:

…to develop a commercially viable video entertainment service (or app) that combines linear video, VoD (video on demand), social media, gaming, discovery and dissemination, personalization, new forms of advertising, community, tCommerce, multiplatform engagement and involves multiple screens, TVs, tablet PCs, PCs, games consoles, smartphones etc.

The venue will be Moscone Center in the urban heart of San Franciscos downtown district on February 7-8. Entrants can come in as teams or also join up with others using our Linkedin Group.

APIs and SDKs will be offered from technology com anies as well as content from production companies which will allow for competitors to create new transmedia experiences around Social TV, Playalong TV, Search and Discovery, Smart TV, Online Gaming and other Multiplatform and Multiscreen Engagement innovation.

 Follow us on:

Linkedin Twitter.com Facebook

events.name: AT&T Aspire Mobile App Hackathon - Los Angeles
events.about:
Have an app idea or need an app built for your business?

This special education focused Mobile App Hackathon is an event produced by the AT&T Developer Program, in coordination with Real Office Centers and AT&T Aspire, designed for attendees (technical & non-technical) to build apps/mobile apps, get fed, compete for prizes across different categories and most importantly: meet new people and scout for teammates to work on new or current projects. Our hackathon will introduce you to the latest cutting edge tools to help deploy your own app with a website backend, fully hosted in the cloud.

We Supply: Quick presentations and code samples that help to bootstrap your hacking, food to keep you going, and caffeine to keep you awake. Along with technical senseis to assist you in building faster, smarter, and with new tools.

You Bring: Your laptop, skills & ideas. Come with a collaborative, team focused mindset and/or team up in advance on Twitter/Facebook/Google+ via the #atthack hashtag. Whether you are a backend person and code in Ruby/PHP/.NET or are a designer and only work with Illustrator, you are invited to attend this event. Every group needs a good balance of talent and your development skills are needed!

Event Schedule.  The following is a list of the weekends agenda:

  • Friday - February 8th
     
    • 06PM - Friday Evening - Kickoff event with drinks, networking, and developer dating.
    • 07PM - Friday Evening - Lightning Talks begin sharply at 7PM featuring technical discussions from local tech leaders and featured event sponsors
    • 08PM - Friday Evening - Idea Pitches and Team Formation
  • Saturday - February 9th
     
    • 10AM - Saturday Morning -  The fun continues with an all day hackathon. Work with the teams that you formed on Friday night to produce the app spec’d out the night before. Senseis will be available throughout the entire event to help you code up your solution.
    • 01PM - Saturday Afternoon -  Lunch is served; coding continues
    • 07PM - Saturday Night -  Dinner is served; coding continues
  • Sunday - February 10th
     
    • 10AM - Sunday Morning -  The excitement concludes with a final half day to polish your app. Continue to work with your team to put the finishing touches on your app. Senseis will be available throughout the entire event to help you code up your solution. App submissions will be accepted throughout the day with a deadline of 4PM Sunday.
    • 01PM - Sunday Afternoon -  Lunch is served; coding continues
    • 04PM - Sunday Evening - Promptly at 4PM, teams will begin pitching their ventures. Pitches are limited to three (3) minutes per team.
    • 06PM - Sunday Evening - Winners are announced!*

*Time is approximately and will vary based on number of entries.

 


Prizes. The following prizes are experiential and geared towards accelerating you towards a successful business as well as expanding your network and industry knowledge:

  • Best Hackathon Overall App 
    • 1st Place
      • $500 in Gift Cards for the team to split
      • $5,000 donated from AT&T to the teams choice of non-profit organizations** 
    • 2nd Place
      • $300 in Gift Cards for the team to split
      • $3,000 donated from AT&T to the teams choice of non-profit organizations**
    • 3rd Place
      • $200 in Gift Cards for the team to split
      • $1,000 donated from AT&T to the teams choice of non-profit organizations**
  • Best App using AT&T APIs (Click for more info)
    • Entire team seeded with Sierra Wireless 4G LTE Devices and one (1) month of 1GB DataConnect Service (Max 3) [compliments of Sierra Wireless]

Judging Criteria. Apps will be judged based on the criteria below and weighted accordingly.  

  • 33% Weight - Ability to clearly articulate what your app does
  • 33% Weight - Originality of idea
  • 33% Weight - Use of Node.JS, Sencha, cloud9ide.com, Heroku, and other technologies
Social Media. 
  • Follow us @hackathonlive for live updates and photos from the event
  • Like us on Facebook! https://www.facebook.com/AttMobileAppHackathon

 

Speakers

 
Alex Donn, Senior Marketing Manager at AT&T, is based out of sunny Seattle! His passion is educating developers young and old about mobile application development best practices through events like hackathons that fuse the collective interests of multiple technology and business leaders. He loves bacon and is allergic to all types of gluten. Dan Gould, co-founder of Chill, is an entrepreneur and technologist who specializes in designing social and communications software. He also works with sophisticated optimization algorithms, user data analysis, and various economic tools. Prior to Chill, Dan was co-founder of Ad.ly and co-founder of Newroo which was acquired in 2006 by Fox Interactive Media/NewsCorp.
Max Katz, Head of Community and Developer Relations for Tiggzi (http://tiggzi.com), a cloud-based HTML5, jQuery Mobile and PhoneGap mobile app builder. He loves trying out new and cool REST APIs in mobile apps. You can find out what Max is up to on his blog: mkblog.exadel.com and Twitter: @maxkatz. Alex Gaber, is an API Evangelist for Layer 7 Technologies a company that manages over 200 APIs spanning business and government.  Starting as a web developer 15 years ago, Alex grew up in Silicon Valley and is an active member in the hackathon and developer community.  He has a passion for building web and mobile applications that integrate numerous APIs and ideas to create innovative and unique solutions.
   
   

Senseis

events.name: Test The Web Forward - Sydney
events.about:

Weve organized a number of hackathons and are organizing another one in February that will help you get there! Representatives from W3C, Google, Mozilla, Microsoft, Opera, and Adobe will be on hand to guide you.

During these hackathons, you will discover new web features and learn how to write tests that will help browsers make implementations of these features consistent.

events.name: TenHands WebRTC Hackathon
events.about:
JOIN THE HACKATHON

Calling all developers to join us on Feb 9th doing what you do best: building amazing stuff. Hack from 11AM to 6PM usingTenHands WebRTC API to build a cool product or service that demonstrates the use of real-time audio/video communications.

TenHands is offering a grand prize of $2,500 to the winning team. Second and third prizes of $1500 and $750 will be awarded as well. Space is limited - register today!

Proposed Schedule (subject to change):

10 am - Kickoff
11 am - Hacking begins
12 pm - Pizza arrives
  4 pm - Krispy Kreme arrives
  6 pm - Hacking ends, dinner served
  7 pm - Demos
  8 pm - Winners chosen and prizes awarded

FAQS

What is WebRTC?

WebRTC is a free, open project that enables web browsers with Real-Time Communications (RTC) capabilities via simple Javascript APIs. The WebRTC components include network, audio, video components that are required for building real-time audio and video applications. The WebRTC initiative is a project supported by Google, Mozilla and Opera.

Can I form a team at the Hackathon?

Absolutely. If you dont have a team, register now and you can always find other members or join an existing team at the event.

Is there a limit on the team size?

Not really, but we encourage a team size of 3-4.

What programming languages can I use?

TenHands offers a server side REST API and a javascript client API for integrating with web applications. You are free to use any language (python, PHP, java, etc) on the server side as long as it can talk REST. On the client side, you will have to use our javascript API to integrate with your web app.

What APIs can I use?

To qualify for a prize, you will have to build an application that uses the TenHands API and demonstrates real-time video/audio/data communication. In addition to the TenHands API, you are free to use any other vendor APIs that you like. For example, you could use APIs from Box, Dropbox, Twilio, Linkedin, facebook, salesforce or Asana in conjunction with the TenHands API to do a mash-up.

events.name: Windows Hackathon at Princeton University
events.about:
Windows Hackathon, 02/15-02/17 in Sherrerd. Build apps for the fastest growing apps platform in the world and win tablets, Xbox bundles, phones and gift cards. 

With over 40 million licenses sold and over 35,000 apps debuting in just over a month, Windows 8 is the fastest growing platform in the world today. In Windows Phone 8, you have a serious player in the world of smartphones with over 100,000 apps available for download. Are you excited about the immense opportunities available to you courtesy these platforms and their explosive growth? Do you get excited about building apps for mobile or tablet devices and win exciting prizes? Then youre at the right place!

Microsoft is proud to host its second annual hackathon on campus at Princeton University this Spring. Build apps for Windows 8 or Windows Phone 8 and win awesome prizes such as tablets, phones and Xbox bundles(see details below). Onsite expertise will be available to get you started and help demo the apps! There will be snacks and food going during the entire weekend! Every app that demos automatically wins $20 and you are eligible to submit your app to the Windows Store immediately! 

Come join us and RSVP now!
 
Prizes

Best Windows 8 App: Win8 Tablet(s) (Microsoft Surface RT, Samsung Ativ 500t)*

Best Windows Phone 8 App: Win Phone 8 device(s) (ex. Nokia Lumia 820/920)*

Best Princeton-specific App: Xbox 360 Bundle(s) (Console + Kinect)*

Best Designed App: Xbox 360

Honorable Mention: Office Suite, Windows 8 license, XBox games

All Apps that demo: $20 gift-card

*maximum of 2 to be given away for teams of 2 or more.

Development Environment

In order to develop apps for Windows 8 and Windows Phone 8, you will need the following: 

  • OS: Windows 8 (64-bit)
  • Visual Studio Express 2012
  • Windows 8 or Windows Phone 8 Developer Accounts (free via the DreamSpark students program)

For those looking to install Windows 8, we have the following options:

  1. Friend 016:
    We have reserved 16 machines in Friend 016 for the duration of the hackathon. Friend 016 machines will have Windows 8 VMs and Visual Studio Express 2012 for you to use to develop apps for Windows 8 and Windows Phone 8. Please let us know before or at the start of the event if you would like to use this option.


  2. Windows machines:
    You can get a Windows 8 license (for free!) using the DreamSpark program hosted by the CS Department at Princeton. The software is available to CS Undergraduates (BSE, AB, and PAC),CS Graduate students, students currently enrolled in CS courses, and faculty in the department. OIT does offer Microsoft software to all students at a discount and you can find out more information at this link:

    http://www.princeton.edu/oitstore

    Windows 8 is available for download for free from our Microsoft DreamSpark site:

    https://msdnaa.cs.princeton.edu/

  3. OS X machines:
    For those using OS X on Mac devices, we recommend the installing Windows 8 with BootCamp. To get a Windows 8 DVD and license, please follow steps outlined in Option (2) above.

It is recommended that you set up your development environment before the event begins to utitlize the weekend to hack away. However, we will have experts at the event who can help you through the process should there be any difficulties. 

Helpful Guides:

Windows 8 for Developers

Windows Phone 8 for Developers

events.name: Evernote Cal Poly Hackathon
events.about:
About the Evernote Hackathon at Cal Poly SLO
Are you a software engineer, web developer or graphic designer? Are you a marketer, or startup enthusiast?
Come spend 24 hours to build a mobile app, web site or project that will make life better at Cal Poly and your community.

It’s a weekend of hacking where you can think up ideas, pitch concepts to each other, join into teams to quickly build as much as you can, and present the results.

It’s a great way for you to make new connections, learn skills, and get feedback from mentors and your peers. It will be a creative, supportive environment – OK, maybe just a little bit competitive too. Bring your energy and enthusiasm and let’s build together.

During the weekend we will have experienced mentors and speakers on hand to help you with key technologies and the Evernote API. On Sunday everyone will demo to each other and will get feedback from an expert panel. After voting by the judges, and by all of you, we will celebrate with some fun prizes.

Many past hackathons have led to student teams forming start ups of their own -- we hope to see you join that notable list!

How to Sign Up
Help us get the right mix of participants by picking the right ticket: if you can code, pick the developer/engineer ticket, 60 available. Can you do HTML or visual design but not code? Pick the designer/UX ticket, 40 available. Content developer, marketer or startup enthusiast? Pick Ideas / Other, 20 available. There is no charge to attend but we can only fit a limited number of people so sign up early.

The event will be held in the Bonderson Engineering Center at Cal Poly in San Luis Obispo. You will need to be there on Friday evening February 15th for the kickoff night. Bring your ideas and we will help everyone form teams. Hack on your project starting that Saturday morning and over the weekend and show your demo on Sunday, February 27th.

Plenty of food and refreshments will be provided on Saturday and Sunday, just bring your own computer. 

Powered by Evernote, Computer Engineering Society (CPES), Graphic Communications (GrC) and the Computer Engineering Program (CPE) at Cal Poly

events.name: IDEATHON
events.about:
What in tarnation is an Ideathon?

It’s like this. You’ve got an idea, but it’s just that - An idea.  No business model. No brand. No real clue as to how to move forward with it. Ring any bells?! An ideathon is a chance to pitch that idea and, in an afternoon, go from nothing to something.

What if I don’t have an idea?

If you’re looking to team up with someone with a great concept, this is a fantastic opportunity to hear lots of pitches and get involved at the earliest stage of development.  

Who should come?

  • If you have an idea– pitch it at one of our events, join forces with people to help develop your idea from nothing to something and maybe even meet your new Co-Founder!

If you don’t- have a current project, you’ll get to hear a load of pitches & you’ll get to work on the one you like – helping to develop it in any way you can – and again, maybe you’ll meet the yin to your yang... the Bonnie to your Clyde... the Adrian to your Rocky.

How’s it different?

Our events are about rolling up your sleeves and developing a business concept. But! It’s not a hackathon. It’s almost a pre-hackathon. The emphasis is less on building something and more on developing a concept in any way possible, whether it’s a business model, a pitch, a demo, and MVP, UX sketches... You name it.

What’s the catch?

  We want to keep it small and high quality, so sign up now before it’s too late. 

And Finally... 
Be sure to join our community on Meetup to meet other like-minded individuals!
 http://bit.ly/SmGmHL

events.name: Open Data Day 2013 Hackathon - DC Metro Area
events.about:
International Open Data Day is Saturday, February 23, 2013. Were holding a hackathon in the DC area, an event for technologists and data enthusiasts to collaborate on open data projects. Anyone with an interest in open data is encouraged to come.

Bring ideas, your laptop, and help create solutions to make data more open and make better use of open data. Well decide on projects and form groups at the beginning of the event.

All other details are TBD. Stay tuned.

This event is being organized by Josh Tauberer (GovTrack) and Eric Mill (Sunlight Foundation).

Last year...

The last open data day hackathon in DC was on Dec. 3, 2011. It was co-hosted by POPVOX (Josh Tauberer) and Wikimedia DC (Katie Filbert). See what we did on the post-event recap athttps://www.popvox.com/features/opendataday2011. The theme of our hackathon was open government data, and participants worked on improving access to U.S. law, scanning federal spending for anomalies following Benford’s Law, understanding farm subsidy grants, building local transit apps, and keeping Congress accountable. Only about half of the participants were programmers, but everyone found a way to be involved.

events.name: Hack-o-motive
events.about:
WHAT IS HACK-O-MOTIVE?
Hack-o-motive is a two-day challenge that focuses on re-imagining the car shopping experience by bringing together consumers, dealers, manufacturers, designers and technologists to shatter the status quo. In providing this creative, collaborative platform for groups of intellectually diverse thinkers, our goal is to generate a surge of bold and innovative new ideas. A panel of judges will then evaluate the proposed solutions to determine the winners.

WHY HAVE THIS EVENT?
Car buying is the second biggest purchase behind a home for most consumers and remains an unpleasant, anxiety-filled experience that has changed little even with the benefit of online resources. By bringing together the right mix of thought leaders and change agents, we believe we can reinvent the car buying experience from the ground up.
